is that it's not just the time spent it's how you spend the time you can spend 10,000 hours on something but if

interface interface is technical data about the library this is things about its features its functionality its usage
what does it do and how do you use it uh this information is easy to find usually on the read me if it's a GitHub
project uh these are the bits that are interface this is basically what everyone starts with everyone starts with readme readme is a time honored uh
tradition here's one from 1936 about how to use the telephone uh and it's pretty awesome because it's basically like
every readme on GitHub here's all the bullet points how to operate how to answer how to clear how to make calls
great right all it's missing is installation instructions guess that comes in the five books supplement later
um so here's a more modern version slightly more modern version read me tells you what it is and how you do it
and so when you're considering interface you're basically trying to figure out the question you're trying to answer is will this code be sufficient for what I
needed to do and most often in most projects comes them read me in some cases you may need to drop it in and
mess around for a while if the documentation is particularly poor but that's one category of evaluation uh the
second is activity this is things like looking at the number and recency of commits on GitHub you don't want
something that's abandoned right looking at the GitHub issues and PLL requests how long have they Lan dormant uh it
also includes things like when was the last release how up to- dat are the official docs in general with this category of evaluation we're trying to
figure out how often is it updated How likely am I get help from the maintainer get a pull request merge things like that it's this stuff
activity uh is this project sufficiently active that I can depend on it next category is popularity uh
meaning amongst other developers how easy will it be to find help when I run into a problem can I hire somebody who's
used it already uh How likely is it someone else has already fixed a bug by the time I get there to figure this out we look at things like how many
tutorials and blog posts are there when I Google it right how many stack Overflow questions are there and have any of them been
answered um we also ask other developers we know either directly or in kind of a
meta way through Hacker News or Reddit or Twitter or something like that uh we look to see whether it's been mentioned

tests these are things that I call accessibility and it's this one's a little weird the other three categories are pretty straightforward and they have

yeah is it 420 yet that's what that usually means
um so if you still think about web applications as a a some markup and a
and a veneer of interactivity on top and if you're web application is still thinking about pages in that way um then

complex than something like in sh query cookie so one source is the set of

uh and often times in a single project uh you may have more than one thing that's that's inter that's uh
contributing to this judgment so for any given decision accessibility is kind of the most

amount of ease or the amount of unease that you feel when you're working with a framework
um and the last thing to consider is that even once you're explicitly thinking about accessibility it may not
